108.heading: Horina, Hans--Miscellanea.
108.title: "Das Amerikanische Abenteuer"
108.author: von Eckart Sackmann
notes: Begins: "Im Jahre 1906 engagierte die Chicago Tribune eine Reihe bekannter deutscher Zeichner, um die Comicbeilage der Wochenendausgabe zu gestalten. Was mit viel gutem Willen begonnen hatte, erwies sich binnen Kürzester Zeit als katastrophale Fehlkalkulation."

Mainly a reprinting (in English) of a Chicago Tribune article of Apr. 29, 1906, introducing its new German comics artists. Includes illustrations by Lyonel Feininger, Hans Horina, Victor Schramm, Karl Pommerhanz, Karl Staudinger, Lothar Meggendorfer, and August von Meissel, all from the Chicago Tribune, 1906-1907.

notes: Letters not separately captioned from Brian Caden, Anthony Pate, Paul Tubbs, Jimmy Berydas, Doug Bishop and Alan Nordmark.

132.heading: Hormel, Al.
132.title: "Bursting Balloons: Silents, Please!"
132.author: Al Hormel
132.appears_in: p. 24-27 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 1 (Autumn 1994) 1. Word balloons. 2. Blondie. I. Hormel, Al. II. Silents, Please! Call no.: PN6700.H6v.1no.1

133.heading: Hormel, Al.
133.title: "Complaint Department"
133.author: by Al Hormel
133.appears_in: p. 28-31 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 4 (1997).
notes: Column of various complaints, among others that most strips should not be reprinted in complete collections, that original art should not be donated to libraries, that four different cartoonists have been named Frank Miller, and that some cartoonists are too good for the medium.

134.heading: Hormel, Al.
134.title: "Déjà Vu All Over Again"
134.author: by Al Hormel
134.appears_in: p. 22-24 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 2 (=no. 6) (Winter 1999).
notes: Nostalgic look at scary moments (in Boob McNutt, Dick Tracy, The Gumps) and dramatic moments (in Flash Gordon and For Better or For Worse), with mentions of Toots and Casper, Rugrats, Baby Blues, Zits, and Rose is Rose.

135.heading: Hormel, Al.
135.title: "The Funny Big Apple"
135.author: by Al Hormel
135.appears_in: p. 24-26 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 3 (=no. 7) (1999).
notes: Column on newspaper strips in New York in the 1930s, and on Al Capp and Li'l Abner. -

136.heading: Hormel, Al.
136.title: "The Good, the Bad and the Hideous"
136.author: by Al Hormel
136.appears_in: p. 26-28 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).
notes: Summary: General comments about the art of comic strips, showing samples with discussion of the work of Charles Payne on S'Matter Pop and Art Huhta on Mescal Ike.

137.heading: Hormel, Al.
137.title: "Lions and Tigers and Bears? Oh, My!"
137.author: comentary by Al Hormel
137.appears_in: p. 28-30 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 2 (1995).
notes: Summary: Discusses funny animal comics, particularly expressing the question of why various artists have chosen to use anthropomorphic characters.

138.heading: Hormel, Al.
138.title: "My Five-Year-Old Can Draw Better Than That!" p. 40-42 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 3
138.author: [No author]
notes: On bad drawing in comic strips, with samples from T.E. Powers, A.E. Hayward, and Norman Marsh.

139.heading: Hormel, Al.
139.title: "Silver Linings"
139.author: by Al Hormel
139.appears_in: p. 26-29 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 1 (=no. 5) (1998).
notes: Summary: Describes the success of artists who have taken over established comic strips, including Bud Sagendorf and Bobby London (Popeye), Jim Raymond, Stan Drake and Denis LeBrun (Blondie), Dick Moores and Jim Scancarelli (Gasoline Alley), Leonard Starr (Annie), Selby Kelly (Pogo), George Wunder (Terry and the Pirates), Jerry Scott and Guy and Brad Gilchrist (Nancy)

140.heading: Hormel, Al.
140.title: "Watching Peanuts Grow"
140.author: by Al Hormel
140.appears_in: p. 24, 26-27 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 4 (=no. 8) (2000).
notes: Column on Peanuts, with short sections on strips adapted to radio and television, on For Better or For Worse, and on New Yorker cartoons.

141.heading: Hormel, Al.
141.title: "You Certainly Have Changed!" p. 40-47 in Hogan's Alley, v. 1, no. 3
141.author: [No author]
notes: About comic strip characters that changed in appearance, with samples of Skippy, Daisy Mae, Happy Hooligan, Li'l Abner, Mary Worth, and Little Orphan Annie.

142.heading: Hormel, Howard--Miscellanea.
142.title: The Who's Who of American Comic Books
142.author: Jerry Bails & Hames Ware

143.title: La Hormiga y la Pulga
143.author: T
143.appears_in: de Iriarte: p. 173-179 in Novelas Inmortales, no. 557 (Jul. 20, 1988).

144.title: "Las Hormigas Gigantes"
144.author: [No author]
144.series: Hombre Plástico) 8 p. in Doll Man, no. 4
notes: Cover title: "El Horror de las Hormigas Gigantes."

146.heading: Hormone Therapy.
146.title: "The Olsen Twins in about 40 Years"
146.author: Michael Fry.
notes: Key words: Plugging videos, anti-growth hormone therapy.

147.heading: Hormones.
147.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
147.author: [No author]

148.heading: Hormones.
148.title: "Elemental, but Highly Effective!"
148.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: Gaylord demonstrates his approach to dating: hormones.

149.heading: Hormones.
149.title: "The Illegal Use of Growth Hormones is on the Rise Among Cats"
149.author: by Nicole Hollander.

150.title: Horace and Dotty Dripple
notes: Family comic book based on the newspaper strip Dotty Dripple, and continuing the comic book also titled Dotty Dripple.
